facts.text: The appellant was employed in 1939 in the Bengal Nagpur Railway as a clerk in the workshop at Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: The facts in Civil Appeal No. 46 of 1956-the facts in the companynected appeals are similar and do number require to be stated-are that the appellant was employed in 1939 in the Bengal Nagpur Railway as a clerk in the workshop at Nagpur.

facts.text: In 1946 when the State took over the administration of the Railway, it gave option to the employees to continue in service on the terms set out in a document dated July 5, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: In 1946 when the State took over the administration of the Railway, it gave option to the employees to companytinue in service on the terms set out in a document dated July 5, 1946.

facts.text: The appellant accepted those terms and continued in service on the conditions mentioned in that document.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant accepted those terms and companytinued in service on the companyditions mentioned in that document.

facts.text: The Governor-General promulgated the Railway Services (Safeguarding of National Security) Rules, 1949, which came into force on May 14, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Acting in exercise of the powers companyferred by ss. 241 2 , 247 and 266 3  of the Government of India Act, 1935, the Governor-General promulgated certain rules called the Railway Services  Safeguarding of National Security  Rules, 1949, hereinafter referred to as the Security Rules, and they came into force on May 14, 1949.

facts.text: On July 6, 1950, the General Manager of the Bengal Nagpur Railway issued a notice to the appellant under R. 3 of the Security Rules stating that there was reason to believe that the appellant was engaged in subversive activities and calling upon him to show cause why his services should not be terminated.

anchor.surface_text: On July 6, 1950, the General Manager of the Bengal Nagpur Railway issued a numberice to the appellant 1056 under R. 3 of the Security Rules stating that in view of the facts recited therein, there was reason to believe that the appellant was engaged in subversive activities and calling upon him to show cause why his services should number be terminated.

facts.text: He was also placed under suspension from that date.

anchor.surface_text: He was also placed under suspension from that date.

facts.text: On July 29, 1950, the appellant sent his explanation denying the allegations contained in the notice dated July 6, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On July 29, 1950, the appellant sent his explanation denying the allegations companytained in the numberice dated July 6, 1950.

facts.text: The Committee of Advisers held an enquiry on September 8, 1950, and after hearing the appellant found that the charges against him mentioned in the notice were true.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was then referred to the Committee of Advisers, who held an enquiry on September 8,1950, and after hearing the appellant found that the charges against him mentioned in the numberice were true.

facts.text: Acting on this report, the General Manager terminated the services of the appellant on April 3, 1951, giving him one month's salary instead of notice.

anchor.surface_text: Acting on this report, the General Manager terminated the services of the appellant on April 3, 1951, giving him one months salary instead of numberice.

facts.text: On February 3, 1951, the appellant had filed the writ petition in the High Court of Nagpur challenging the validity of the notice dated July 6, 1950, and the order of suspension following thereon.

anchor.surface_text: Meantime, on February 3,1951, the appellant had filed the writ petition, out of which Civil Appeal No. 46 of 1956 arises, in the High Court of Nagpur challenging the validity of the numberice dated July 6, 1950, and the order of suspension following thereon.

facts.text: The order of dismissal dated April 3, 1951, having been passed during the pendency of this Petition, the appellant had his petition amended by adding a prayer that that order also was bad.

anchor.surface_text: The order of dismissal dated April 3, 195 1, having been passed during the pendency of this Petition, the appellant had his petition amended by adding a prayer that that order also was bad.

facts.text: By their judgment dated November 16, 1951, the learned Judges held that it was unnecessary to decide whether the Security Rules were void as, assuming that they were, the orders terminating the services of the petitioners could be sustained under R. 148 of the Railway Establishment Code.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was heard along with others, in which the same questions were raised, and by their judgment dated November 16, 1951, the learned Judges held that it was unnecessary to decide whether the Security Rules were void as, assuming that they were, the orders terminating the services of the petitioners companyld be sustained under R. 148 of the Railway Establishment Code.

facts.text: The petitions were dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the petitions were dismissed, and the present appeals have been preferred against these orders on a certificate under Art. 132  1  and Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution.

I have decided with the prior approval of the President that your services should be terminated under Rule 3 of the Railway Services (Safeguarding of National Security) Rules, 1949.'

holdings.text: The orders terminating the services of the appellants cannot be upheld under R. 148 of the Railway Establishment Code as the authorities purported to take action only under R. 3 of the Security Rules, with notices and orders expressly reciting R. 3.

anchor.surface_text: 1 . On the first question, it appears clearly from the record that the authorities purported to take action only under the Security Rules. - The notice dated July 6, 1950, was avowedly issued under R. 3 of those rules. It was in the scrupulous observance of the procedure prescribed therein that the explanations of the appellants in answer to the charges were taken, and the matters were referred to the Committee of Advisers for enquiry. And above all, the orders terminating the services of the appellants, in terms, recite that they were made under R. 3 of the rules, as for example, the notice dated April 3, 1951, given to the appellant in Civil Appeal No. 46 of 1956, which runs as follows

holdings.reasoning_summary: Record shows notices issued under R.3, procedure followed under Security Rules, orders recite R.3; respondents did not plead R.148; difficulty in equating powers but no final opinion needed as willing to test under Security Rules.

holdings.text: The Security Rules do not infringe Article 14 of the Constitution as the classification of persons engaged in subversive activities has an intelligible differentia bearing reasonable relation to national security.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that if the persons dealt with under these rules form a distinct class having an intelligible differentia which bears a reasonable relation to the purposes of the rules, then there would be no infringement of Art.14. But it is argued that the expression subversive activities which forms the basis of the classification is vague and undefined in that even lawful activities could be roped therein, and that such a classification cannot be said to be reasonable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies twin test of reasonable classification; subversive activities in context of national security precise, not vague; distinguishes Anwar Ali Sarkar; rejects vagueness based on charges.

holdings.text: The Security Rules and impugned orders do not infringe Article 19(1)(c) as they do not prevent appellants from continuing as Communists or trade unionists and there is no fundamental right to continued State employment.

anchor.surface_text: It is next contended that the impugned orders are in contravention of Art. 19 1 c , and are therefore void. The argument is that action has been taken against the appellants under the rules, because they are Communists and trade unionists, and the orders terminating their services under R. 3 amount, in substance, to a denial

holdings.reasoning_summary: Termination affects employment, not association rights; rights under Art.19(1)(c) unchanged post-order; no right to continued employment apart from Art.311.

holdings.text: Termination under R.3 of Security Rules is not dismissal or removal under Article 311 as it is not punitive, involves no premature termination of tenure or loss of accrued benefits, and stands on same footing as discharge under R.148.

anchor.surface_text: it is then contended that the procedure prescribed by the Security Rules for the hearing of the charges does not satisfy the requirements of Art. 311, and that they are, in consequence, void. But Art. 311 has application only when there is an order of dismissal or removal, and the question is whether an order terminating the services of the employees under R. 3 can be said to be an order dismissing or removing them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedents (Parshotam Lal Dhingra, etc.); no punishment as tenure terminable on notice, benefits preserved under R.7; no re-employment bar.

holdings.text: The impugned orders are valid under the Security Rules as procedure was followed: notice given, explanation considered, enquiry by Committee of Advisers held, and prior approval obtained.

anchor.surface_text: On July 6, 1950, the General Manager of the Bengal Nagpur Railway issued a notice to the appellant 1056 under R. 3 of the Security Rules stating that in view of the facts recited therein, there was reason to believe that the appellant was engaged in subversive activities and calling upon him to show cause why his services should not be terminated. He was also placed under suspension from that date. On July 29, 1950, the appellant sent his explanation denying the allegations contained in the notice dated July 6, 1950. The matter was then referred to the Committee of Advisers, who held an enquiry on September 8,1950, and after hearing the appellant found that the charges against him mentioned in the notice were true. Acting on this report, the General Manager terminated the services of the appellant on April 3, 1951, giving him one months salary instead of notice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show compliance with R.4 (notice, show cause, representation, enquiry); R.3 satisfied (opinion on subversive activities prejudicial to security, approval).

holdings.text: The impugned orders were passed by competent authorities as required under R.3 (General Manager with prior approval of President/Governor-General).

anchor.surface_text: I have considered your representation to me in reply to this office letter No. Con T/2 I MP/82 dated 6-7-1950 and am of the opinion that you are engaged and associated with others in subversive activities in such manner as to raise doubts about your reliability and am satisfied that your retention in public service is prejudicial to national security. I have decided with the prior approval of the President that your services should be terminated under Rule 3 of the Railway Services (Safeguarding of National Security) Rules, 1949.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Orders recite satisfaction of competent authority (General Manager) and prior approval; no defect alleged or shown.

holdings.text: Security Rules have no retrospective operation; past conduct can form basis for opinion that employee is engaged or likely to engage in subversive activities prejudicial to national security.

anchor.surface_text: It is next contended by Mr. Umrigar that the charges which were made against the appellant in Civil Appeal No. 46 of 1956 in the notice dated July 6, 1950, have reference to events which took place prior to the coming into force of the Security Rules, which was on May 14, 1949, and that the order terminating the services of the appellant based thereon is bad as giving retrospective operation to the rules,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules prospective (action on present engagement or suspicion); antecedents provide materials for forming opinion on current/future reliability without retrospectivity.

precedents.citation: Sambandam v. General Manager, I. Ry. 1 I.L.R. 1953 Mad. 229

anchor.surface_text: Sambandam v. General Manager, I. Ry.  1  and Prasadi v. Works Manager, Lillooah  2  and that is also companyceded by .Mr. Ganapathy Iyer. If then the power to terminate the service under the Security Rules is different from the power to discharge under R. 148 when the procedure prescribed therein is number followed, it must be equally so when, as here, it has been followed, for the companyplexion of the rules cannot change according as they are companyplied with or number. That means that the Security Rules have an independent operation of their own, quite apart from R. 148. We do number, however, desire to express any final opinion on this question, as Mr. Ganapathy Iyer is willing that the validity of the orders in question might be determined on the footing that they were passed under R. 3 of the Security Rules, without reference to R. 148. That renders it necessary to decide whether the Security Rules are unconstitutional, as companytended by the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: and Prasadi v. Works Manager, Lillooah  2  and that is also companyceded by .Mr. Ganapathy Iyer. If then the power to terminate the service under the Security Rules is different from the power to discharge under R. 148 when the procedure prescribed therein is number followed, it must be equally so when, as here, it has been followed, for the companyplexion of the rules cannot change according as they are companyplied with or number. That means that the Security Rules have an independent operation of their own, quite apart from R. 148. We do number, however, desire to express any final opinion on this question, as Mr. Ganapathy Iyer is willing that the validity of the orders in question might be determined on the footing that they were passed under R. 3 of the Security Rules, without reference to R. 148. That renders it necessary to decide whether the Security Rules are unconstitutional, as companytended by the appellants.  Ila . The first ground that is urged against the validity of the Security Rules is that they are repugnant to Art. 14.

anchor.surface_text: definiteness. Now, the principles applicable for a determination whether there has been a proper and valid classification for purposes of Art. 14 have been the subject of companysideration by this Court in a number of cases, and they were stated again quite recently in Budhan Choudhry and others v. The State of Bihar 3 , and there is numberneed to repeat them. The only point that calls for decision in these appeals is whether the classi- fication of persons on the basis of subversive activities is too vague to be the foundation of a valid classification. Mr. Umrigar insists that it is, but his elaborate argument amounts to numbermore than this that the expression subversive activities may take in quite a variety of activities, and that its companytents are therefore wide. It may be that the companynotation of that expression is wide, but that is number to say that it is vague or indefinite.

anchor.surface_text: cribe the hearing of the charges does number satisfy the requirements of Art. 311, and that they are, in companysequence, void. But Art. 311 has application only when there is an order of dismissal or removal, and the question is whether an order terminating the services of the employees under R. 3 can be said to be an order dismissing or removing them. Now, this Court has held in a series of decisions that it is number every termination of the services of an employee that falls within the operation of Art. 311, and that it is only when the order is by way of punishment that it is one of dismissal or removal under that Article. Vide Satish Chandra Anand v. Union of India  1  , Shyam Lal The State of Uttar Pradesh and the Union of India  2  , State of Bombay v. Saubhagchand M. Doshi  3  , and Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India  4  .

precedents.case_name: Satish Chandra Anand v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: Not every termination of service falls within Art.311; only punitive orders are dismissal or removal

precedents.citation: Shyam Lal The State of Uttar Pradesh and the Union of India 2 1955 1 S.C.R. 26, Civil Appeal No. 182 Of 1955

anchor.surface_text: Vide Satish Chandra Anand v. Union of India  1  , Shyam Lal The State of Uttar Pradesh and the Union of India  2  , State of Bombay v. Saubhagchand M. Doshi  3  , and Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India  4  . The question as to what would amount to punishment for purposes of Art. 311 was also fully companysidered in Parshotam Lal Dhingras case  supra . It was therein held that if a person had a right to companytinue in office either under the service rules or under a special agreement, a permature termination of his services would be a punishment. And, likewise, if the order would result in loss of benefits already earned and accrued, that would also be punishment.

precedents.case_name: Shyam Lal v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Not every termination of service falls within Art.311; only punitive orders are dismissal or removal

precedents.citation: State of Bombay v. Saubhagchand M. Doshi 3 Civil Appeal No. 65 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: Shyam Lal The State of Uttar Pradesh and the Union of India  2  , State of Bombay v. Saubhagchand M. Doshi  3  , and Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India  4  . The question as to what would amount to punishment for purposes of Art. 311 was also fully companysidered in Parshotam Lal Dhingras case  supra . It was therein held that if a person had a right to companytinue in office either under the service rules or under a special agreement, a permature termination of his services would be a punishment. And, likewise, if the order would result in loss of benefits already earned and accrued, that would also be punishment. In the present case, the terms of employment provide for the services being terminated on a proper numberice, and so, numberquestion of permature termination arises.

anchor.surface_text: State of Bombay v. Saubhagchand M. Doshi  3  , and Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India  4  . The question as to what would amount to punishment for purposes of Art. 311 was also fully companysidered in Parshotam Lal Dhingras case  supra . It was therein held that if a person had a right to companytinue in office either under the service rules or under a special agreement, a permature termination of his services would be a punishment. And, likewise, if the order would result in loss of benefits already earned and accrued, that would also be punishment. In the present case, the terms of employment provide for the services being terminated on a proper numberice, and so, numberquestion of permature termination arises. Rule 7 of the Security Rules preserves the rights of the employee to all the benefits of pension, gratuities and the like, to which they would be entitled under the rules.

precedents.case_name: Parshotam Lal Dhingra v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: What amounts to punishment for purposes of Art.311: premature termination where right to continue, or loss of accrued benefits
precedents.cited_holding: if a person had a right to continue in office either under the service rules or under a special agreement, a premature termination of his services would be a punishment. And, likewise, if the order would result in loss of benefits already earned and accrued, that would also be punishment

It was in the scrupulous observance of the procedure prescribed therein that the explanations of the appellants in answer to the charges were taken, and the matters were referred to the Committee of Advisers for enquiry. And above all, the orders terminating the services of the appellants, in terms, recite that they were made under R. 3 of the rules, as for example, the notice dated April 3, 1951, given to the appellant in Civil Appeal No. 46 of 1956, which runs as follows

anchor.surface_text: On July 6, 1950, the General Manager of the Bengal Nagpur Railway issued a notice to the appellant 1056 under R. 3 of the Security Rules stating that in view of the facts recited therein, there was reason to believe that the appellant was engaged in subversive activities and calling upon him to show cause why his services should not be terminated. He was also placed under suspension from that date. On July 29, 1950, the appellant sent his explanation denying the allegations contained in the notice dated July 6, 1950. The matter was then referred to the Committee of Advisers, who held an enquiry on September 8,1950, and after hearing the appellant found that the charges against him mentioned in the notice were true. Acting on this report, the General Manager terminated the services of the appellant on April 3, 1951, giving him one months salary instead of notice.
In the result, the petitions were dismissed, and the present appeals have been preferred against these orders on a certificate under Art. 132
n that the enquiry companyducted by the authorities was defective, and that there was numberproper hearing as provided by the rules, but we declined t

anchor.surface_text: I have considered your representation to me in reply to this office letter No. Con T/2 I MP/82 dated 6-7-1950 and am of the opinion that you are engaged and associated with others in subversive activities in such manner as to raise doubts about your reliability and am satisfied that your retention in public service is prejudicial to national security. I have decided with the prior approval of the President that your services should be terminated under Rule 3 of the Railway Services (Safeguarding of National Security) Rules, 1949.
In the result, the petitions were dismissed, and the present appeals have been preferred against these orders on a certificate under Art. 132

In the result, the petitions were dismissed, and the present appeals have been preferred against these orders on a certificate under Art. 132
